description: From Middle English macche, mecche, from Old English mæċċa, ġemæċċa (“companion, mate, wife, one suited to another”), from Proto-West Germanic *makkjō, *gamakkjō (“partner, equal”), from Proto-Germanic *makô, from Proto-Indo-European *mag- (“to knead, work”). Compare Danish mage (“mate”), Icelandic maki (“spouse”).

entries.meaning: (sports) A competitive sporting event such as a boxing meet, a baseball game, or a cricket match.
examples: My local team are playing in a match against their arch-rivals today.

entries.meaning: Any contest or trial of strength or skill, or to determine superiority.
examples: A solemn match was made; he lost the prize.

entries.meaning: Someone with a measure of an attribute equaling or exceeding the object of comparison.
examples: He knew he had met his match.

entries.meaning: A candidate for matrimony; one to be gained in marriage.
Equality of conditions in contest or competition.
A pair of items or entities with mutually suitable characteristics.
examples: The carpet and curtains are a match.

entries.meaning: (metalworking) A perforated board, block of plaster, hardened sand, etc., in which a pattern is partly embedded when a mould is made, for giving shape to the surfaces of separation between the parts of the mould.

verbs.description: match (third-person singular simple present matches, present participle matching, simple past and past participle matched)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To agree; to be equal; to correspond.
examples: Their interests didn't match, so it took a long time to agree what to do together.
These two copies are supposed to be identical, but they don't match.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To agree with; to be equal to; to correspond to.
examples: His interests didn't match her interests.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a successful match or pairing.
examples: They found out about his color-blindness when he couldn't match socks properly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To equal or exceed in achievement.
examples: She matched him at every turn: anything he could do, she could do as well or better.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To unite in marriage, to mate.
To fit together, or make suitable for fitting together; specifically, to furnish with a tongue and groove at the edges.
(programming) To be an example of a rule or regex.
examples: The behavior matched one or more rules and was rejected by an edit filter.

description: From Middle English macche, mecche (“wick (of a candle)”), from Old French mesche, meische, from Vulgar Latin micca (compare Catalan metxa, Spanish mecha, Italian miccia), which in turn is probably from Latin myxa (“nozzle, curved part of a lamp”), from Ancient Greek μύξα (múxa, “lamp wick”).

entries.meaning: A device made of wood or paper, at the tip coated with chemicals that ignite with the friction of being dragged (struck) against a rough dry surface.
examples: He struck a match and lit his cigarette.
